ProjectDescr.Title: Aging GEM phenotype study (CRTC2 AKO adipocyte research)
ProjectDescr.Description: This study reveals that the increase in CRTC2 in adipocytes during aging promotes cellular senescence, leading to adipose tissue dysfunction and aging-related chronic metabolic disorders. CRTC2 in adipocytes inhibits BCAA catabolism through decreased PPAR gamma expression, and the resulting mTORC1 activation induces cellular senescence and impairs mitochondrial homeostasis. Furthermore, increased SASP secretion from senescent adipocytes promotes adipocyte remodeling by inhibiting adipocyte precursor differentiation and regulating immune cells. In adipocyte-specific CRTC2 knockout mice, the activation of the BCAA-mTORC1 axis is limited, suppressing the development of aging-induced chronic metabolic disorders. These findings suggest that modulating CRTC2 or BCAA catabolism could be a potential strategy to attenuate the aging process.

Grant.Title: Establishment of a new pipeline for the aging phenotyping of genetically modified mice
